singleton-pattern-detail.title: The Government Office and the Singleton Pattern
singleton-pattern-detail.subtitle: An Indian Bureaucracy Tale

story.introduction: In every Indian city, there exists a legendary figure known as 'Sharma Ji' — the government office manager who ensures that there's only one official instance of any important government office. Just as there can only be one Prime Minister's Office, some software objects should have only one instance.
story.quote: One office, one authority, no confusion! That's how government works efficiently.

timeline.title: The Chaos of Multiple Offices
timeline.description: Initially, different departments tried to create their own 'official' offices, leading to confusion and conflicting decisions.

timeline.title: Sharma Ji's Solution
timeline.description: Sharma Ji implemented a system where only one instance of each critical office could exist, with controlled access for all departments.

timeline.title: The Single Point of Truth
timeline.description: Now, everyone knows exactly where to go for official decisions, and there's no confusion about which office is the 'real' one.

timeline.title: Handling Concurrent Visitors
timeline.description: Sharma Ji ensures that even when multiple people try to access the office simultaneously, they all get directed to the same instance.

timeline.title: Lazy Initialization
timeline.description: The office is only set up when someone actually needs it, saving government resources until the office is required.

technicalExplanation.definition: The Singleton pattern ensures that a class has only one instance and provides a global point of access to that instance.
keyCharacteristics: Only one instance of the class can exist
Global access point to the instance
Lazy or eager initialization options
Thread-safe implementation considerations
Private constructor to prevent direct instantiation
Static method to get the instance
advantages: Avoids variable pollution in global scope
disadvantages: Threading issues if not implemented correctly

Modern JavaScript Singleton
Python Singleton Implementation
codeExamples.code:
class GovernmentOffice:
    _instance = None
    
    def __new__(cls):
        if cls._instance is None:
            print("Sharma Ji: Government office is now established!")
            cls._instance = super(GovernmentOffice, cls).__new__(cls)
            cls._instance.office_name = "Central Government Office"
            cls._instance.documents = []
        return cls._instance
    
    def process_document(self, document):
        self.documents.append(document)
        print(f"Sharma Ji processed: {document}")
    
    def show_status(self):
        print(f"Office: {self.office_name}")
        print(f"Documents processed: {len(self.documents)}")

# Usage
office1 = GovernmentOffice()
office2 = GovernmentOffice()

print(office1 is office2)  # True - same instance

Singleton can implement interfaces and be passed as parameters, static classes cannot.

factory-method-pattern-detail.title: The Magical Toy Workshop and the Factory Method Pattern
factory-method-pattern-detail.subtitle: A Tale of Toy Creation

story.introduction: In a bustling market in Old Delhi, there exists a magical toy workshop run by Master Toymaker Gupta. While ordinary toy shops sell pre-made toys, Gupta's workshop creates custom toys based on each child's personality. The workshop doesn't need to know exactly what toy it will create until the child arrives, just as the Factory Method pattern lets subclasses decide which objects to create.
story.quote: I don't make toys; I create joy. Each child deserves a toy that matches their spirit!

timeline.title: The Challenge of Custom Toys
timeline.description: Master Gupta faced a problem: how to create different toys for different children without rewriting his entire workshop process each time.

timeline.title: The Workshop Framework
timeline.description: Gupta designed a standard workshop process (the abstract creator) that defined all the steps for toy creation but left the specific toy creation to specialized craftsmen (concrete creators).

timeline.title: Specialized Craftsmen
timeline.description: Different craftsmen (concrete creators) joined the workshop, each specializing in creating different types of toys (concrete products) like musical toys, puzzle toys, or action figures.

timeline.title: The Magic of Customization
timeline.description: When a child enters the workshop, Gupta assesses their personality and assigns the appropriate craftsman, who then creates the perfect toy using their specialized factory method.

timeline.title: Expanding the Workshop
timeline.description: As new toy types became popular, Gupta simply hired new specialized craftsmen without changing the overall workshop process.

technicalExplanation.definition: The Factory Method pattern defines an interface for creating an object, but lets subclasses decide which class to instantiate. It lets a class defer instantiation to subclasses.
keyCharacteristics: Creates objects through inheritance
Encapsulates object creation in a method
Subclasses implement the factory method to create specific objects
Connects parallel class hierarchies
Follows the dependency inversion principle
whenToUse: When a class can't anticipate the type of objects it needs to create
When a class wants its subclasses to specify the objects it creates
When you want to localize the knowledge of which class gets created
When you need to create different products depending on context
When you have a hierarchy of creators that parallels a hierarchy of products
advantages: Eliminates the need to bind application-specific classes into your code
Provides hooks for subclasses to extend the factory
disadvantages: May lead to many small subclasses
Can become complex if there are many product types
Requires inheritance which can be limiting in some languages
Can be overkill for simple object creation scenarios

Simple Factory uses a single class with a static method, while Factory Method uses inheritance and polymorphism.
Factory Method focuses on creating different product types, while Builder focuses on constructing complex objects step by step.

builder-pattern-detail.title: Patel Uncle and the Builder Pattern
builder-pattern-detail.subtitle: An Indian Wedding Tale

story.introduction: In every Indian community, there exists a legendary figure known as 'Patel Uncle' — the ultimate wedding planner who can orchestrate the most elaborate wedding celebrations with precision and flair. Just as Indian weddings are complex, multi-day affairs with countless moving parts, software systems often require complex objects built from many components.
story.quote: Building perfect wedding is like building perfect object — you need right steps, right order, and plenty of patience!

timeline.title: The Complex Wedding Challenge
timeline.description: The Sharma and Patel families wanted to arrange a wedding but were overwhelmed by the complexity involving venue, catering, music, ceremonies, and more.

timeline.title: Enter Patel Uncle: The Master Builder
timeline.description: Patel Uncle promised to build their wedding step by step, handling all complexities while giving families exactly what they wanted.

timeline.title: The Building Process
timeline.description: Rather than asking families to coordinate with dozens of vendors, Patel Uncle had a systematic approach with clear methods for each aspect.

timeline.title: The Big Reveal
timeline.description: When all elements were configured, Patel Uncle brought everything together into a magnificent celebration that exceeded expectations.

technicalExplanation.definition: The Builder pattern allows you to create complex objects step by step, separating the construction of a complex object from its representation.
keyCharacteristics: Separates object construction from representation
Provides better control over construction process
Allows creating different representations using same process
Creates objects step by step
Hides complex construction details from client
whenToUse: When parts must be built in specific sequence
advantages: Code is more readable and maintainable
disadvantages: May impact performance due to additional objects

observer-pattern-detail.title: The Village Crier and the Observer Pattern
observer-pattern-detail.subtitle: A Tale of News Distribution

story.introduction: In a small village in rural India, Pandit Ramesh serves as the village crier, responsible for keeping everyone informed about important events. Instead of going door to door with news, villagers subscribe to his announcements by hanging a special flag outside their homes. Whenever there's news, Pandit Ramesh walks through the village and announces it only to those who have subscribed, just as the Observer pattern notifies interested objects about state changes.
story.quote: Information is like water - it should flow freely to those who thirst for it, but not flood those who don't!

timeline.title: The Communication Problem
timeline.description: The village was growing, and Pandit Ramesh couldn't efficiently inform everyone about every piece of news, especially since not everyone was interested in all types of announcements.

timeline.title: The Subscription System
timeline.description: Pandit Ramesh introduced colored flags (the observer registration) that villagers could hang outside their homes to indicate which types of news they wanted to receive.

timeline.title: News Categories
timeline.description: Different news types were established: red flags for emergencies, blue for weather forecasts, green for agricultural updates, and yellow for social events.

timeline.title: The Notification Process
timeline.description: When news arrived (state change), Pandit Ramesh would walk through the village and announce it only to houses displaying the corresponding colored flag.

timeline.title: Dynamic Subscriptions
timeline.description: Villagers could change their subscriptions at any time by simply changing the flags outside their homes, without disrupting the overall system.

technicalExplanation.definition: The Observer pattern defines a one-to-many dependency between objects so that when one object changes state, all its dependents are notified and updated automatically.
keyCharacteristics: Defines a one-to-many relationship between objects
Loose coupling between subject and observers
Subject notifies all registered observers automatically
Observers can be added or removed dynamically
Implements the 'push' or 'pull' model for updates
whenToUse: When changes to one object require changing others, and you don't know how many objects need to change
When an object should be able to notify other objects without making assumptions about who these objects are
When a change to one object requires changing others, but the number of objects that need to change is unknown or dynamic
For implementing distributed event handling systems
advantages: Loose coupling between subject and observers
Dynamic relationships between objects at runtime
disadvantages: Unexpected updates if observers are unaware of each other
Memory leaks if observers aren't properly unregistered
Potential performance issues with many observers

codeExamples.title: Village News System Implementation
Python Village News System
codeExamples.code:
from enum import Enum
from abc import ABC, abstractmethod

# News Type Enum
class NewsType(Enum):
    EMERGENCY = 1
    WEATHER = 2
    AGRICULTURE = 3
    SOCIAL = 4

# Observer Interface
class Villager(ABC):
    @abstractmethod
    def receive_news(self, news_type, news):
        pass

# Concrete Observer
class VillageHouse(Villager):
    def __init__(self, family_name):
        self.family_name = family_name
    
    def receive_news(self, news_type, news):
        print(f"{self.family_name} received {news_type.name} news: {news}")

# Subject
class VillageCrier:
    def __init__(self, name):
        self.name = name
        self.subscribers = {news_type: [] for news_type in NewsType}
    
    # Subscribe to a news type
    def subscribe(self, news_type, villager):
        if villager not in self.subscribers[news_type]:
            self.subscribers[news_type].append(villager)
            print(f"{self.name}: New subscriber for {news_type.name} news!")
    
    # Unsubscribe from a news type
    def unsubscribe(self, news_type, villager):
        if villager in self.subscribers[news_type]:
            self.subscribers[news_type].remove(villager)
            print(f"{self.name}: Subscriber removed from {news_type.name} news.")
    
    # Notify all subscribers of a specific news type
    def announce_news(self, news_type, news):
        print(f"{self.name} announces {news_type.name} news: {news}")
        
        for villager in self.subscribers[news_type]:
            villager.receive_news(news_type, news)

# Client code
def main():
    # Create the village crier
    pandit_ramesh = VillageCrier("Pandit Ramesh")
    
    # Create some villagers
    sharma_house = VillageHouse("Sharma Family")
    patel_house = VillageHouse("Patel Family")
    singh_house = VillageHouse("Singh Family")
    
    # Subscribe villagers to different news types
    pandit_ramesh.subscribe(NewsType.EMERGENCY, sharma_house)
    pandit_ramesh.subscribe(NewsType.EMERGENCY, patel_house)
    pandit_ramesh.subscribe(NewsType.EMERGENCY, singh_house)
    
    pandit_ramesh.subscribe(NewsType.WEATHER, sharma_house)
    pandit_ramesh.subscribe(NewsType.AGRICULTURE, patel_house)
    pandit_ramesh.subscribe(NewsType.SOCIAL, singh_house)
    
    # Announce some news
    pandit_ramesh.announce_news(NewsType.EMERGENCY, "Heavy rainfall expected tonight. Secure your homes!")
    pandit_ramesh.announce_news(NewsType.AGRICULTURE, "The rice harvest will begin next week.")
    
    # Unsubscribe and then announce again
    pandit_ramesh.unsubscribe(NewsType.EMERGENCY, patel_house)
    pandit_ramesh.announce_news(NewsType.EMERGENCY, "The flood warning has been lifted.")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

comparisons.difference: Observer defines a one-to-many relationship, while Mediator defines a many-to-many relationship with centralized control.
Observer focuses on notification of state changes, while Command encapsulates a request as an object.
Observer typically involves direct references between subject and observers, while Publish-Subscribe often uses a message broker as an intermediary.
